comments.commentBody: As an immigrant (albeit one that doesn't care much for conformity), I recently decided to change my first name. Not the least because it was ethnic sounding or hard to pronounce or open to discrimination: in fact it is spelt and pronounced identically to an Anglican/American female, and I'm male. After a nearly 10 year continual struggle with a gender disambiguation process that was sometimes funny but mostly a nuisance, I decided to alter a single vowel to give myself a very American male name. Keeps me out of trouble, by keeping people from making assumptions when they hear my name... or someone else's non-American one!

Marian Smith from CIS who was quoted in the article would be the first correct the urban myth that immigrants names were "changed at Ellis Island". The inspectors merely tried to verify the information on the ship registers that had been prepared in the European ports of departure.

If you think about it, where would this Ellis Island name change been recorded in 1900 or 1910? There was no computer database nor any identity/internal passport documents issued to immigrants as they left Ellis Island.

Once they left Ellis Island, they were free to call temselves whatever they liked. It only became a problem when they applied for citizenship and the government tried to find their arrival information with the spelling used on the original ship register.

That's not to say that government bureacracies didn't alter/miswrite the names of immigrants once they settled here. My grandfather emigrated to the U.S. in 1911 and he ended up having a "government name" with a unique spelling when he had to deal with the VA or Social Security. The U.S. Army got his surname wrong when he was drafted in WWI and the misspelling stuck. Out of the more than 80 million surnames listed in the Social Security Death Index (SSDI), his is the only one with that "government name" spelling.

I was born and raised in the United States, my parents are Chilean of Basque descent, and I was given a very traditional French-Basque name.

Recently, I've wanted to change my name to something a bit more traditional in the U.S. The problem is that there isn't a translation
to my name in the Anglo/Celtic influence (John, Robert, Tim, etc.).

But, really, in a multicultural cesspool like the U.S, is it necessary?

My family arrived in the 17th century. But my name is very unique and apparently, quite difficult to pronounce (it's Welsh). It is extremely rare for someone to pronounce it correctly the first time and I often have to correct them more than once. Should I change my name? Does it matter that I was "here first"?

Problem is that the america of today concentrates on the "E Pluribus" but not the "Unum".  Immigrants can keep their surnames however it seems they dont want to assimilate.  This will only lead to chaos and the disintegration of the country in the long run.
OK, Wags -- I'll bite.  Did I make a mistake in that corner, or is there a completely obvious connection between spoon and neck that I'm overlooking?
Sorry about the corrupt Wednesday Across Lite file. Jim Horne reported it late last night. While it awaits replacement, you can download an unlocked file HERE.
Can't open it either. I've tried both my Macs and even tried to download from cruciverb.com. It's corrupt. It's past 10pm on the east coast, so it's in the "puzzle archive" list. Help, please.

And what about the cartoon? Excellent!

Much easier than I expected though I fell into the ETE for SEL trap.Very clever. I was somehow trying to make a journey segment into END or EGG or .....

@4 Wags--I am old enough to get the connection between spoon and neck, but I'll bet not everyone here is.
Yikes -- I retract the question!  Dope slap on my already red face.  Time for some sleep...

And there's no place for him to appeal. Baseball, basketball, football, etc. have unions where one can appeal a fine or punishment. It's called, "due process." Golf on the other hand has no such venue. The PGA rules with an iron fist, dictating rules and conduct. I agree that rules on the course and strictly adhering to said rules, no matter how ridiculous, is important as it allows for a level playing field. However, the case at hand regards conduct in an event that's not really part of the game and there should be some flexibility and judgment. (Would the PGA have ruled differently if Furyk was late because he was saving a hild from a burning buiding?)

(see Dustin Johnson at Pebble)
This entire story is very sad.  Now be decent and let it go quietly away.
I'm thinking he will plug the phone in overnight from now on. hehe. Isn't that when most people charge their phones??

Mr. Furyk seems to be a gentleman and a good sport, but this was a pro-am. Perhaps the clipboard boys should have let him join the group but disallow the results from the standings. I'm sure the others in his foursome wanted to play a round of golf with a top-ranked pro, rather than sit in the clubhouse and pick through a rulebook.

Still, I always employ multiple alarms and wakeup calls when meetings simply cannot be missed or delayed.
This makes me like Furyk!  He seems to have a sense of humor about himself. I'll start to follow his efforts now.
Well, Elin wasn't putting up with it like Hillary did. Good for her- she's got more intregrity than that.

Sorry, the golf rule may or may not have been stupid or unnecessarily harsh. But this is his job, and there's $TEN MILLION at stake. No excuse for not checking the cell phone battery, calling the hotel for a wake up call, or going out to some store and spend the price of a drink or two to get a real alarm clock. Someone that dumb or sloppy doesn't DESERVE to be excused...

This was a fun solve; much more fun than last Thursday's! Several smiles when the light bulb went off and I got the tricky ones.

I also wasn't aware that my favorite tree had been celebrated in song. I look forward to June every year when they are in bloom, especially now that the trees are recovering from the hurricane damage of a few years ago.

Wags, you're right - as nouns, spoon and NECK don't have anything to do with each other. However, if you think of them in the old-fashioned context of "billing and cooing," then spoon and NECK do relate, as verbs with similar meanings.

Mmm.. Elin.. I'd love to meet you and your money. Girls- forget about learning- marry a bazillionaire, suffer his boring life for a few years and a few kids and GET RICH! That being said, I don't have any sympathy for Tiger- any society that pays someone billions to hit a golf ball into a hole is a sick, twisted society indeed. Elin will be in the South of France next summer while Tiger is double-bogeying 17 and nailing some hapless stripper in the Holiday Inn.
Who cares? Golfers aren't known for being particularly bright.
#4, maybe he wasn't staying in a hotel. some players rent houses at these tournaments. whatever happened, most unfortunate. shades of that famous seinfeld episode with the runner and the marathon.

Golf is the silliest game ever and this proves it. The only thing sillier is the fact that people in power still wear a suit and tie, as if that means more than intelligence, personality, and character.

Cell Phone as a wakeup call instrument? It is height of absurdity for a professional level of work and/or play.

I do not know the Golf rule is stupid or not, but it does not make much sense when it a just a game, Golf officials loosen up my friends. I think you are just being stupid when you have no sense of proportion.

Ummmm...

Regarding the issue of "lateness" and how it inconveniences other people who may be relying on you to show up at the time you agreed to appear - the NY Times covered this topic a few weeks ago in the City Room Blog:

Complaint Box | Running Late

http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com...

Some may find it interesting.

comments.userLocation: New Jersey, not far from the Barclays course
comments.commentBody: Bummer for him, yet I think this is pretty endearing.  Hey Jim, are you married?  No, if he was his wife might have called.  Or not, as she might be tired of playing second to golf. At any rate, it is such a human mistake!  Can we lay off the dude, I am sure he feels bad enough.  It is funny though, isn't it, like a family story told at holiday?
